DataElement.preferredName: Molecular Analysis Laboratory Procedure EBNA-2 PCR Finding Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term that represents the result for Epstein-Barr Nuclear Antigen 2 (EBNA-2) found through molecular analysis using PCR.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Molecular Analysis Laboratory Procedure Epstein-Barr Nuclear Antigen 2 Gene Rearrangement Polymerase Chain Reaction Finding
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A laboratory procedure that involves the study of tissues, cells, and fluids using DNA/RNA analysis techniques for the identification of characteristics and abnormalities at the molecular level._Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting._Epstein-Barr nuclear antigen 2 (487 aa, ~55 kDa) is encoded by the Epstein-Barr virus EBNA2 gene. This protein is involved in the activation of host B-cells._Any DNA sequence rearrangement that results in the creation of a novel protein-coding capacity. Within certain genes, gene rearrangement is a normal part of development, facilitating the affinity maturation of B and T lymphocytes as well as class switching of immunoglobulins._A laboratory method used to make many copies of a specific DNA sequence._Clinical, laboratory or molecular evidence, or absence of evidence of disease.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Techniques for studying or analyzing the genetic composition and mechanisms of living organisms at the molecular level. May refer to the understanding and manipulation of genes (DNA).:A medical procedure that involves testing a sample of blood, urine, or other substance from the body. Tests can help determine a diagnosis, plan treatment, check to see if treatment is working, or monitor the disease over time.

Concepts.definition: A laboratory procedure that involves the study of tissues, cells, and fluids using DNA/RNA analysis techniques for the identification of characteristics and abnormalities at the molecular level.
Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.

Property.preferredName: Epstein-Barr Nuclear Antigen 2 Gene Rearrangement Polymerase Chain Reaction Finding
Property.preferredDefinition: Epstein-Barr nuclear antigen 2 (487 aa, ~55 kDa) is encoded by the Epstein-Barr virus EBNA2 gene. This protein is involved in the activation of host B-cells.:Any DNA sequence rearrangement that results in the creation of a novel protein-coding capacity. Within certain genes, gene rearrangement is a normal part of development, facilitating the affinity maturation of B and T lymphocytes as well as class switching of immunoglobulins.:A method for amplifying a DNA base sequence using multiple rounds of heat denaturation of the DNA and annealing of oligonucleotide primers complementary to flanking regions in the presence of a heat-stable polymerase.  This results in duplication of the targeted DNA region. Newly synthesized DNA strands can subsequently serve as additional templates for the same primer sequences, so that successive rounds of primer annealing, strand elongation, and dissociation produce rapid and highly specific amplification of the desired sequence. PCR also can be used to detect the existence of the defined sequence in a DNA sample.:Clinical, laboratory or molecular evidence, or absence of evidence of disease.

Concepts.definition: Epstein-Barr nuclear antigen 2 (487 aa, ~55 kDa) is encoded by the Epstein-Barr virus EBNA2 gene. This protein is involved in the activation of host B-cells.

Any DNA sequence rearrangement that results in the creation of a novel protein-coding capacity. Within certain genes, gene rearrangement is a normal part of development, facilitating the affinity maturation of B and T lymphocytes as well as class switching of immunoglobulins.

A method for amplifying a DNA base sequence using multiple rounds of heat denaturation of the DNA and annealing of oligonucleotide primers complementary to flanking regions in the presence of a heat-stable polymerase.  This results in duplication of the targeted DNA region. Newly synthesized DNA strands can subsequently serve as additional templates for the same primer sequences, so that successive rounds of primer annealing, strand elongation, and dissociation produce rapid and highly specific amplification of the desired sequence. PCR also can be used to detect the existence of the defined sequence in a DNA sample.
Clinical, laboratory or molecular evidence, or absence of evidence of disease.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Created for 16C0003 Molecular Pathology CRF request by Y.Yakovlev. mc 3/31/17

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The preferred Value Domain to capture a list of findings following an examination or observation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A finding of abnormality following an examination or observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.

Concepts.definition: A finding of abnormality following an examination or observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A finding of normality following an examination or investigation looking for the presence of a microorganism, disease, or condition.

Concepts.definition: A finding of normality following an examination or investigation looking for the presence of a microorganism, disease, or condition.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not yet decided or settled; awaiting conclusion or confirmation.

Concepts.definition: Not yet decided or settled; awaiting conclusion or confirmation.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated VM Short Name to be the Public ID to be consistent with current convention for VM Short Name - DW 10-03-2022

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Data from an original source is not present, accessible or ready for use or service.

Concepts.definition: Data from an original source is not present, accessible or ready for use or service.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Indicates that a test was not performed.

Concepts.definition: Indicates that a test was not performed.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results of evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Positive Finding Negative Finding Unknown Finding Type
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A finding of abnormality following an examination or observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.:A finding of normality following an examination or investigation looking for the presence of a microorganism, disease, or condition.:Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.:Clinical, laboratory or molecular evidence, or absence of evidence of disease.:Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

Concepts.definition: A finding of abnormality following an examination or observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.
A finding of normality following an examination or investigation looking for the presence of a microorganism, disease, or condition.
Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.
Clinical, laboratory or molecular evidence, or absence of evidence of disease.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
